The last one of the Laphroaig Legacy Fund beneficiaries is ReJIG.

Since 2006, Re-JIG has been removing marine litter from the shores of Islay and Jura, lifting a total of over 200 tons of litter. Due to a change in the government’s funding policy, Re-JIG will have a shortfall of £19,000 in 2015 and this deficit will continue to grow, soon making it impossible to keep Islay’s beaches clean.

The Laphroaig Legacy fund is helping ensure this invaluable work continues by commissioning a digital project team to monetise the websites and create an online system that enables tourists to donate a small amounts to keep Islay’s beaches clean. This will generate a regular income to finance not only paid employee’s at Re-JIG, but help purchase equipment for the devoted volunteers who are already committed.

Read more at http://www.laphroaig.com/our-islay/legacy-fund/rejig.aspx Photos from Laphroaig's post

The next Laphroaig Legacy Fund beneficiary we want to introduce is the Islay Canoe Club (ICC) and Kayak Wild Islay (KWI).

Kayal Wild Islay is a local business targeted at tourism whilst providing the use of their equipment to the local Islay Canoe Club which provides this leisure pursuit the locals at very low cost.

As an activity, sea kayaking is a hugely beneficial as develops both environmental awareness along with a number of positive mental and physical skills.

The Laphroaig Legacy Fund shall be working with both ICC and KWI to provide specialist canoes for locals and tourists who may have physical disabilities and to raise awareness of this service in the media, targeted at locals and tourists alike.

Read more at http://www.laphroaig.com/our-islay/legacy-fund/icc-and-kwi.aspx Photos from Laphroaig's post

Islay Ales is the third of our Laphroaig Legacy Fund beneficiaries.

Islay Ales is a small craft brewery producing a range of cask & bottle conditioned beers on the island. The business has been in continuous production since 2004 and whilst the majority of sales are on Islay, export has begun to France, Switzerland, Germany and Japan. It is the aim to continue this steady expansion of the business and increase the work force.

To achieve the increase in production, Islay Ales must have SALSA (Safe And Local Supplier Approval) accreditation, which is becoming a requirement of supermarkets and distributors. The Laphroaig Legacy Fund shall work alongside Islay Ales to fund the SALSA accreditation but also provide a training and development consultant. The combination of the accreditation matched with the training scheme shall not only see this small, family run business expand but will also generate employment opportunities for locals.

Find out more at http://www.laphroaig.com/our-islay/legacy-fund/islay-ales.aspx Photos from Laphroaig's post

Our second Laphroaig Legacy Fun beneficiary is the Argyll College.

The University of Highlands & Islands was established to make higher education accessible to those living in rural areas in Scotland. Argyll College hosts the Islay branch, providing a variety of courses and training programs that are fully accredited and recognised by employers.

The Laphroaig Legacy Fund will help to provide additional IT equipment, improved video conferencing for remote lectures and fund vocational courses to allow more Illeach’s the opportunity to take advantage of skilled work on the island.

Find out more at http://bit.ly/argyllcollege Photos from Laphroaig's post

Let us introduce you to the first one of our Legacy Fund Beneficiaries: 
Celebrating their skills in needlework, The Islay Quilters.

Formed in 1992, a small group of quilters whose aim is to leave a legacy in more ways than one, as not only are they teaching their craft to the new generation of Illeach’s but they also provide a tourist attraction in the form of their shop.

Working with The Laphroaig Legacy Fund, additional machines shall be purchased, a sustainable heating system shall be installed reducing monthly bills and a project team shall help generate PR and a social media presence for Islay Quilters with the objective of driving footfall to their shop, increasing income.

Find out more about them at: http://bit.ly/islayquilters Photos from Laphroaig's post

In Laphroaig’s 200th year, we celebrate the past by looking to the future supporting the sustainability of local businesses, community projects and individual’s skills on Islay.

The Laphroaig Legacy Fund will not only offer financial help but also advice and mentoring for those who are committed to increasing employment, attracting tourism and providing a service to make island life even more attractive. We invited several beneficiaries to join us for lunch at the distillery and celebrate their work.

From next week onwards, every Tuesday we'll give you an insight into some of the great work being achieved by the beneficiaries here on FB. Perhaps you'll remember some of them from Laphroaig Live! Photos from Laphroaig's post

Happy Earth Day to all of our friends around the world!

As you know, for us at Laphroaig, taking care of our environment is very important. The beautiful peat fields and sea are integral in the process of what makes Laphroaig so special. For that reason, sustaining the ecosystem of the island is one of the most important parts of our legacy.

We are very lucky to be able to work and live here.

Cairdeas Origin 2012 is launched

We specially retained some of our very first Cairdeas for the ‘Friends’ 18th birthday expression .This whisky is now between 13 and 21 years old. We then blended it  (50:50) with some new spirit fully matured in quarter casks for 7 years and bottled it without any chill filtering for maximum flavour. It is at 51.2%ABV strength, which was one of the staff’s ideas, so that the last 2 digits match the year of production .It’s a fantastic ‘coming of age’ whisky, we hope you love it as much as we do! 

Will go on sale at our online shop W/C 18th June.

Tasting Notes.
Nose: With a nose that constantly evolves and is full of flavour Cairdeas Origin begins with a quick hint of concentrated orange moving quickly into huge peat flavours, ashy , dusty with hazelnut. It becomes crisp and fresh with cold green apples, grapes and finishing with a fresh cut grassy flavour.

Palate: The flavours evolve slowly on the palate and with great body it begins with white pepper moving into an earthy peaty flavour, some slight salt then purple heather. Huge creamy apricots that last and last and it ends with some charred damp wood. Timeline Photos
We still cut all our peat by hand. It means we can look after our special ingredient and safeguard its future. Timeline Photos
Cutting peat by hand means we can put some back to replenish the bog. Without it, we wouldn’t be able to make our unique whisky. Timeline Photos

These kilns have been here since 1840; we know this from the date on the original stone which is still in the kiln.

The salty air is drawn directly off the sea and mixes with the smoke from the peat. This mixture gives us the unique smoke – the sweetness of the heather and mosses combined with the medicinal tang of the lichens. After about 12 to 13 hours the malted barley is fully ‘peated’. To complete the process we have to continue drying the malt down to 4.5% moisture content, which stops the germination process. We do this by using hot air, which has been heated by surplus hot water from our still house.

We peat first and dry later whereas other distilleries peat and dry at the same time. We do it this way as we find that it gives us a better all round flavour to our spirit. Timeline Photos

Islay peat is very unique.

We still hand cut our peat the traditional way and look after our own peat beds very carefully. It’s important to put the top layer back after cutting, so that the peat will be able to replenish itself over time. After all, it’s been here for millions of years.

There aren’t any forests like there are on the mainland, so our peat is made up of other decaying plant matter – namely heather, mosses and lichens. This makes for a different quality and flavour of peat.
It is the lichens that give our peat the medicinal flavours that are a hallmark of the Laphroaig flavour profile. Timeline Photos
Tuesday means the stills are running. To be honest, the stills are always running here on Islay. Timeline Photos

Our Distillery Community Part 6: A millers tale from Arthur Holyoake and the three key stages of his work...

Drying: When the Barley has germinated and grown to exactly the desired point, it is transferred to the Kiln floor to be spread out and slowly dried over a Peat Fire.  The grains absorb the smoke (the Peat Reek) to give Laphroaig it’s characteristic smoky flavour.
The process of drying is completed using warm air.
 
Resting: The malt is allowed to cool and rest for several weeks in one of our Malt Bins before passing to The Malt Mill.
 
Milling: The malted barley is crushed through two sets of stainless steel rollers, to create grist, a mixture of husk material, coarse and fine flour. Sugars will be extracted from the grist in the mashing process.

My question for you - how long does the barley rest for? Timeline Photos
Peat, the foundation of Laphroaig's Islay malts, is still cut & harvested by hand. Timeline Photos

Lore was created to be a complex marriage of all aspects of Laphroaig. That’s why it’s the richest whisky we’ve ever made. Timeline Photos
We fought to protect our precious water supply. And for good reason. Without the peaty water from the Kilbride stream, Laphroaig wouldn't be the same. Timeline Photos

Our precious water source is the Kilbride stream.

So important is it that a little over 100 years ago we had what has become known as The Water Wars, when a rival distiller tried to divert it from us. After a lengthy court battle we regained our supply. As a result we bought all the land adjoining the stream, some of which is now the Friends of Laphroaig plots.

In the 1930’s we constructed a dam creating The Kilbride Reservoir so that we always have a continuous water supply to the distillery throughout the year. Timeline Photos

The annual Whisky Nosing Competition for Feis Ile got underway tonight at the Ramsay hall at Port Ellen. Each Islay distillery hosts a table on which there are 11 nosing glasses. Of the 11 glasses, there is a whisky from each distillery plus two unaged spirits. It’s for the public to identify them. 

You may be aware that it helps to move the whisky around in the glass before you sniff, but did you know you should also remember to open your mouth? It helps to focus the senses on the aromas rather than the alcohol. Timeline Photos

Thank you Rob Andrew for sending this scrumptious Laphroaig Ice Cream recipe. No doubt it will be made by many FoL's this weekend...
so send your pictures and let us know how you liked it!

400ml double cream
200ml whole milk
120g caster sugar
a vanilla pod
3 egg yolks
50g of dark chocolate chunks
4 table spoons of Laphroaig

Mix the cream, milk, half of the sugar and the vanilla pod together. Bring to the boil and then take off the heat. Meanwhile whisk the egg yolks and the remaining sugar together.
Combine the two mixtures together slowly with 4 table spoons of Laphroaig (Quarter Cask in this instance) and whisk fully. 
Stirring constantly in a pan, bring the mixture to about 80 degrees and take off heat. Refrigerate overnight.

Next day, add the chocolate chunks, place in the ice cream maker and ENJOY! Timeline Photos

The Friends of Laphroaig are 21 years old this weekend!

In 1994, the "Friends of Laphroaig" community was formed as a way to thank all of our friends for their support. We decided to give each ‘Friend’ a square foot plot of land at the distillery - and that we would pay them ‘rent’ of a dram of 10 year old each time they came to visit us.

No one then could have guessed that, 21 years later, over 680,000 plots would have been occupied! Over the years we have had everything from proposals and marriages to sculptures placed on your beloved plots, and visitors from over 100 countries around the world. And for that we can only thank you; our Friends.

So this weekend raise your glasses to celebrate Friendship.

Meet the panel:
The first member of this years panel needs no introductions; It's John Campbell!
John Campbell was named Laphroaig’s distillery manager in 2006, fulfilling a 12-year-old ambition. He is the youngest distiller on the island and the first Ileach (native of Islay) to run Laphroaig in its 199 year history. Since joining Laphroaig in 1994, John has worked across the whole distilling process both at Laphroaig and in distilleries including Tormore, Miltonduff and Ardmore.

In addition to his role as Distillery Manager, John plays a lead role in promoting Laphroaig around the world. This includes running the distillery’s “Friends of Laphroaig” program.

John Campbell grew up in the shadow of Laphroaig, and now, he’s running the distillery! Timeline Photos

Don’t miss this year's Laphroaig Live, coming to you live from New York! Bookmark our countdown clock so you won't miss a second... Laphroaig Live New York 2013. Thursday 26th September 2013 EDT. John Campbell was named Laphroaig’s distillery manager in 2006, fulfilling a 12-year-old ambition. He is the youngest distiller on the island and the first Ileach (native of Islay) to run Laphroaig in its 190 year history. Since joining Laphroaig in 1994, John has worked across the whole distilling…

Our very own John Campbell is currently in Stockholm... in the Friends of Laphroaig lounge no less! He's been debating with Jim Beam's Fred Noe, overseen by Moderator for the Debate, Gavin Lipsith. Why not get behind John and give him a thumbs up? Timeline Photos

After our last question of "If Laphroaig were a film what film would it be" we've been inundated with people asking what our answer was. Well here's what our Distillery Manager John has said "Film that is like Laphroaig would be something like Casablanca as it’s an old classic with great pedigree that stands the test of time. Person thats like Laphroaig would have to be Sean Connery for being Scottish, iconic and having great presence. Song that's like Laphroaig would be Nirvana - come as you are"

Our Distillery Manager John just got asked a great interview question so we thought we'd see what you 
would have said "If Laphroaig were a film, what film would it be and why?"

Our distillery manager John is off to Sweden next week for the Viking Line whisky festival. In honour of it we have produced a one off special bottling for the event.  It's a mixture of 13 - 21 year old Laphroaig casks (first fills, refill bourbons and some hogsheads too). Bottled at 50.5% alcohol and exclusive for the Viking line.
Started mashing again, good to be back up and running! John Campbell - mashing

Looking for something delicious to try out on the weekend? We've got you covered!

Cut and burn

10 ml Laphroaig Select
40 ml Maker’s 
20 ml sea buckthorn purée from fresh sea buckthorn
20 ml freshly squeezed lemon juice
20 ml honey syrup 

Shake all the ingredients and strain into a coupette glass and enjoy!

Cut and Burn was the official Laphroaig Live 2014 pre-drink crafted by the amazingly talented Madeleine Solo Rapp. Timeline Photos

At Laphroaig Live we aired the latest film in our Opinions Welcome series.

In our anniversary year we asked the locals at home on the Isle of Islay to share their candid opinions on what Laphroaig tastes like to them personally. We think it’s fantastic – and so do our friends on Islay, so we hope you do too.
